newsitem.title: UK: Loyalists say Northern Irish peace talks in jeopardy.
newsitem.headline: Loyalists say Northern Irish peace talks in jeopardy.

text.p: Fractious Northern Irish peace talks came under new pressure on Tuesday when pro-British Loyalist parties warned they might soon founder on demands for guerrilla disarmament.

"Unless there is substantial movement on the (arms) decommissioning issue, in all likelihood the multi-party negotiations...will collapse within days," said David Adams, a leader of the Ulster Democratic Party (UDP).

The warning came on the eve of important London talks between British Prime Minister John Major and representatives of the political wings of outlawed Loyalist gunmen operating a two-year-old truce in a battle with anti-British IRA guerrillas.

Amid tightened security against possible Irish Republican Army bombings, British and Irish ministers will hold a late night Wednesday meeting in Belfast to assess prospects of a new IRA guerrilla truce to win a voice in peace talks.
Police in Londonderry city thwarted preparations for a suspected IRA landmine ambush last weekend.
The incident threw a cloud over hopes of an early truce, Britain's bottom-line condition for Sinn Fein, the IRA's political arm, to get a seat in talks.
According to Loyalist sources, the disarmament issue that has long blighted political progress still blocks progress at multi-party talks chaired by former U.S.senator George Mitchell.

They say some mainstream Unionist parties, that are backed by members of the pro-British Protestant majority, are demanding surrender of Protestant weaponry for the PUP and UDP to remain in the talks process.

Adams said in a statement that the decommissioning issue "is being deliberately manipulated by some participants merely to create a circumstances whereby loyalist parties will be excluded from playing any further part in negotiations".
The row is an escalation of a dispute that Sinn Fein maintains is being used by their Unionist political foes to keep them out of talks.
Both the IRA and Loyalist guerrillas have set their faces against unilaterly surrendering weapons in advance of a new political accord ending sectarian and political divisions.
The powerful Ulster Unionists Party (UUP) says that if the IRA calls a truce, a first tranche of republican guerrilla weapons should be given in before Sinn Fein gets to the table.
Sinn Fein is already barred from the Mitchell talks because the IRA ditched a 17-month truce in February and resumed a bombing wave aimed at ending British rule over Northern Ireland.
Britain and Ireland say the IRA must declare a credible truce for Sinn Fein to get into the talks. Disarmament should occur parallel with negotiations, they say.
